choices.text: High myopia and lattice degeneration with new onset of floaters in a phakic
An asymptomatic flap tear in an eye with a cataract that is about to be rendered pseudophakic
An atrophic hole in a phakic patient whose other eye developed a retinal detachment
Lattice degeneration in a pseudophakic patient with a family history of retinal detachment

questions.text: Which of the following is the strongest indication for prophylactic treatment (cryopexy or laser surgery) to prevent rhegmatogenous retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The strongest indication for prophylactic treatment to prevent rhegmatogenous retinal detachment involves evidence of acute onset of symptoms and the presence of vitreous traction. This scenario is best exemplified by new onset of floaters in a patient with predisposing factors like high myopia and lattice degeneration. The decision to treat involves a careful assessment of the risks of treatment versus the risks of leaving the patient untreated.

Explanation of Other Options:

An asymptomatic flap tear in an eye with a cataract that is about to be rendered pseudophakic (Option B): Imminent cataract surgery is considered a less compelling indication on its own. However, the combination of impending cataract surgery with evidence of traction (as implied by a flap tear) becomes a strong indication for treatment.

An atrophic hole in a phakic patient whose other eye developed a retinal detachment (Option C): A history of detachment in the other eye is a less compelling indication for prophylaxis on its own. Atrophic holes typically carry a lower risk of detachment compared to flap tears as they do not involve vitreous traction.

Lattice degeneration in a pseudophakic patient with a family history of retinal detachment (Option D): Lattice degeneration, being pseudophakic (having undergone cataract surgery), and a family history of retinal detachment are considered less compelling indications individually for prophylactic treatment. Without acute symptoms or direct evidence of traction, the immediate risk of detachment in this scenario is lower.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute onset of symptoms (like new floaters) combined with evidence of vitreous traction are the most compelling factors for prophylactic treatment to prevent rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
  • Other factors like a history of detachment in the fellow eye or imminent cataract surgery become stronger indications when combined with evidence of traction.

questions.text: Late onset complications (> 6 weeks) of scleral buckle procedures includes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Buckle extrusion is a late-onset complication of scleral buckle procedures. It is an uncommon complication that may present with pain, bleeding, and infection. The treatment for buckle extrusion is to remove or modify the buckle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Retinal incarceration (Option A): Retinal incarceration is an early complication of scleral buckle procedures.

Choroidal neovascularization (Option C): Choroidal neovascularization is not a complication of scleral buckle procedures.

Choroidal detachment (Option D): Choroidal detachment is an early complication of scleral buckle procedures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Buckle extrusion is a recognized late-onset complication of scleral buckle surgery.
  • Retinal incarceration and choroidal detachment are considered early complications.
  • Choroidal neovascularization is not a complication of scleral buckle procedures.

questions.text: Epiretinal membrane is most commonly associated with which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

An epiretinal membrane (ERM) is most commonly associated with posterior vitreous detachment (PVD).

Explanation of Other Options:

Retinal venous occlusion (Option A): While epiretinal membrane may be associated with retinal venous occlusion, it is not the most common association. Retinal venous occlusion leads to retinal ischemia and edema, which can predispose to ERM formation.

Uveitis (Option B): While epiretinal membrane may be associated with uveitis, it is not the most common association. Uveitis involves inflammation within the eye, which can lead to various retinal complications, including ERM.

Trauma (Option C): While epiretinal membrane may be associated with trauma, it is not the most common association. Ocular trauma can cause damage to the retina and vitreous, contributing to ERM formation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The most common association for an epiretinal membrane (ERM) is posterior vitreous detachment (PVD).
  • ERMs can also be associated with other conditions such as trauma, retinal venous occlusion, and uveitis, but less commonly than with PVD.

questions.text: n which of the following quadrants are retinal dialyses most often found following blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Retinal dialyses are the most common retinal breaks observed after blunt ocular trauma. When caused by blunt trauma, these dialyses are most frequently found in the inferotemporal and superonasal quadrants.

Key Takeaways:

  • Retinal dialyses are the most common retinal breaks following blunt ocular trauma.
  • They are most often located in the inferotemporal and superonasal quadrants after blunt trauma.
  • Patients with a history of blunt trauma require a careful retinal examination with scleral depression once acute symptoms resolve to look for such breaks.

questions.text: There is increased risk of Rhegmatogenous RD in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RD) occurs when liquefied vitreous passes through a retinal break (rhegma) and accumulates beneath the neurosensory retina. The risk of rhegmatogenous RD is increased in several conditions, but Hyperopia is not one of them.

Conditions with increased risk of Rhegmatogenous RD include:

  • High myopes: This is due to peripheral retinal degenerations like lattice degeneration, holes, and breaks, along with liquefaction of the overlying vitreous.
  • Trauma: Ocular trauma can lead to retinal breaks.(Option B ruled out)
  • Aphakia: The absence of the natural lens.
  • Pseudophakia: The presence of an intraocular lens after cataract surgery. (Option A ruled out)
  • Lattice degeneration: A peripheral retinal degeneration that predisposes to retinal breaks.(Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is associated with conditions that lead to retinal breaks and vitreous liquefaction.
  • High myopia, trauma, aphakia, pseudophakia, and lattice degeneration are all risk factors for rhegmatogenous RD.
  • Hyperopia is generally associated with a lower risk of rhegmatogenous RD compared to myopia.

Explanation:

Shafer's sign, characterized by pigments in the anterior vitreous (often described as "tobacco dusting"), is a feature seen in fresh Retinal Detachment (RD).

  • Other signs of RD include a decrease in visual acuity.
  • Hypotony can also be observed, as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE.
  • A detached retina typically appears convex in configuration, with a corrugated surface and free undulation.
  • A retinal break is usually identified at the periphery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Congenital glaucoma (Option B): Congenital glaucoma is characterized by elevated intraocular pressure in infants, leading to optic nerve damage and corneal enlargement (buphthalmos). It does not present with Shafer's sign.

ROP (Retinopathy of Prematurity) (Option C): ROP is a retinal vascular proliferative disorder affecting premature infants, which can lead to retinal detachment in advanced stages. While it can cause RD, Shafer's sign specifically refers to vitreous pigment associated with RD.

Stargardt's disease (Option D): Stargardt's disease is a macular dystrophy causing central vision loss and characteristic macular changes like a "beaten bronze" appearance or flecks. It does not involve Shafer's sign or retinal detachment as a primary feature.

Key Takeaways:

  • Shafer's sign (pigments in the anterior vitreous or "tobacco dusting") is a distinctive indicator of Retinal Detachment (RD).
  • Other signs of RD include decreased visual acuity, hypotony, and characteristic changes in the configuration of the detached retina.

questions.text: Subretinal demarcation line or watershed line is seen in-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Demarcation lines, also known as subretinal demarcation lines or watershed lines, are characteristic features of chronic (or old) Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RRD). These lines are formed by the proliferation of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) at the junction between the flat and detached areas of the retina. They can be pigmented or non-pigmented, appearing in linear or curved forms, concentric around the initial retinal break. These lines may limit the spreading of subretinal fluid, which is a typical feature of chronic RRD.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fresh Rhegmatogenous RD (Option A): Fresh RRD is characterized by a convex, deep, mobile elevation of the retina. Other signs include loss of choroidal pattern extending to the ora serrata, the presence of retinal breaks, and a slightly opaque retina with dark blood vessels. Shafer's sign, involving pigments in the anterior vitreous ("tobacco dusting"), is also a feature of fresh RD. Demarcation lines are not typically seen in fresh RD.

ROP (Retinopathy of Prematurity) (Option C): ROP is a retinal vascular proliferative disorder affecting premature infants, which can lead to tractional retinal detachment. While advanced ROP can cause retinal detachment, the primary characteristic used to describe it does not include subretinal demarcation lines as a defining feature.

RP (Retinitis Pigmentosa) (Option D): RP is a group of inherited retinal degenerations characterized by progressive vision loss, attenuated retinal vessels, optic disc pallor, and bone-spicule pigmentation. This condition does not primarily involve retinal detachment with demarcation lines.

Key Takeaways:

  • Demarcation lines are a clear sign of chronic or old Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment, indicating long-standing RPE proliferation at the interface of the detached and attached retina.

choices.text: It is caused due to fibrous bands in the vitreous
It presents with floaters and photopsia
It may extend till ora serrata

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement that Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RRD) is caused by fibrous bands in the vitreous is not true. Fibrous bands in the vitreous are primarily responsible for causing Tractional Retinal Detachment, not Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment. RRD occurs when liquefied vitreous passes through a retinal break and accumulates beneath the neurosensory retina.

Explanation of Other Options:

It presents with floaters and photopsia (Option B): Patients often experience the sudden onset of floaters (new vitreous opacities) and photopsia (flashes of light) as symptoms of an acute rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. These symptoms arise from vitreous traction on the retina.

It may extend till ora serrata (Option C): A rhegmatogenous retinal detachment can originate from a break anywhere in the retina and, if untreated, can progress to involve large portions of the retina, often extending towards the ora serrata (the anterior boundary of the retina).

Surgery is the primary treatment (Option D): Once a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is diagnosed, surgical intervention is the primary and most effective treatment to reattach the retina and prevent permanent vision loss. Common surgical approaches include scleral buckling, vitrectomy, or pneumatic retinopexy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RRD) is caused by a retinal break allowing liquefied vitreous to pass into the subretinal space.
  • Fibrous bands in the vitreous are characteristic of Tractional Retinal Detachment, not RRD.
  • Common symptoms of RRD include floaters and photopsia.
  • RRD can extend to the ora serrata if left untreated.
  • Surgery is the primary treatment for RRD.

questions.text: Which gas is used in Pneumatic Retinopexy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Pneumatic Retinopexy, an expansile gas is injected into the vitreous cavity to push the neurosensory retina back towards the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). After the retina is reapproximated, the retinal break is sealed with a laser. The gases commonly used for this procedure are Sulphur Hexafluoride (SF6) and Perfluoropropane (C3F8).

Explanation of Other Options:

Carbon dioxide (Option A): Carbon dioxide is a gas used in various medical procedures, but it is not typically used as an expansile gas for pneumatic retinopexy.

Nitrous oxide (Option B): Nitrous oxide is commonly used as an anesthetic gas, not as an intraocular tamponade agent in retinal surgery.

Oxygen (Option D): Oxygen is essential for respiration but is not used as an intraocular gas for retinal reattachment procedures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pneumatic retinopexy involves injecting an expansile gas into the vitreous cavity to reattach the retina.
  • The primary gases used for this procedure are Sulphur Hexafluoride (SF6) and Perfluoropropane (C3F8).

questions.text: Causes of Exudative RD are all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exudative Retinal Detachment (RD) occurs when exudative fluid, primarily from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space, leading to retinal detachment. Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) is not listed as a cause of Exudative RD.

  • Causes of Exudative RD include:
    • Inflammatory conditions such as choroiditis, choroidal vasculitis, and posterior scleritis.
    • Choroidal tumors like melanoma, hemangioma, and metastasis.
    • Toxemia of pregnancy.
    • Malignant hypertension.
    • Coats disease.
  • Exudative RD typically presents with floaters (due to vitritis) but no photopsia, visual field defects, and loss of vision if the macula is involved.
  • Signs include a detached retina with a convex and smooth surface, no visible break, and shifting fluid.
  • Treatment for Exudative RD involves systemic steroids and treating the underlying cause.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Scleritis (Option A): Posterior scleritis is explicitly mentioned as an inflammatory condition that can cause exudative RD.
  • Toxemia of pregnancy (Option C): Toxemia of pregnancy is explicitly listed as a cause of exudative RD.
  • Coats Disease (Option D): Coats Disease is explicitly listed as a cause of exudative RD.

Key Takeaways:

  • Exudative Retinal Detachment results from fluid accumulation from the choroid into the subretinal space.
  • Common causes include various inflammatory conditions, choroidal tumors, toxemia of pregnancy, malignant hypertension, and Coats disease.
  • Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) is an ischemic event affecting retinal blood supply and is not a cause of exudative RD.

questions.text: Retinal Detachment may be treated by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surgery is the primary treatment for retinal detachment. Retinal detachment can be treated by Scleral buckling surgery. In this procedure, the sclera is indented by attaching an explant (buckle), which pushes the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) inwards towards the neurosensory retina. Subretinal fluid is drained, and the retinal break is closed by laser or cryotherapy. Other surgical options for retinal detachment include Pneumatic retinopexy and Pars plana vitrectomy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Enucleation (Option B): Enucleation is the surgical removal of the entire eyeball. This procedure is typically performed for severe trauma, intraocular tumors, or painful blind eyes, not as a primary treatment to repair a retinal detachment.

Evisceration (Option C): Evisceration is the surgical removal of the contents of the eyeball, leaving the scleral shell and extraocular muscles intact. Similar to enucleation, it is not a procedure aimed at reattaching the retina but is used for conditions like severe infection, trauma, or painful blind eyes.

Ramibizumab (Option D): Ranibizumab (likely what "Ramibizumab" refers to) is an anti-VEGF (Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor) agent. It is used to treat conditions involving abnormal blood vessel growth or leakage, such as wet age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD) and diabetic macular edema, not for the surgical repair of retinal detachment.

Key Takeaways:

  • Retinal detachment is primarily treated with surgical procedures aimed at reattaching the retina.
  • Key surgical treatments include scleral buckling, often combined with cryotherapy or laser to seal the break.
  • Other surgical options for retinal detachment include pneumatic retinopexy and pars plana vitrectomy.
  • Enucleation and evisceration are globe removal procedures, and Ranibizumab is an anti-VEGF medication, none of which are primary treatments for retinal detachment.

questions.text: All of the following are used in the treatment of retinal detachment except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Several surgical procedures are used for the treatment of retinal detachment, including Scleral buckling, Pneumatic retinopexy, and Pars plana vitrectomy. Transpupillary thermotherapy (TTT) is not mentioned as a treatment for retinal detachment.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Scleral Buckling (Option A): This is a surgical procedure for retinal detachment where the sclera is indented with a buckle to push the RPE inwards towards the neurosensory retina, often combined with subretinal fluid drainage and laser or cryotherapy to close the break.
  • Pneumatic retinopexy (Option B): This procedure involves injecting an expansile gas into the vitreous cavity to push the neurosensory retina towards the RPE, followed by laser to seal the break. Commonly used gases include Sulphur Hexafluoride (SF6) and Perfluoropropane (C3F8).
  • Vitrectomy (Option C): Pars plana vitrectomy is listed as a surgical option for retinal detachment. This procedure involves removing the vitreous gel from the eye.

Key Takeaways:

  • Surgical treatments for retinal detachment include scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy, and pars plana vitrectomy.
  • Transpupillary thermotherapy (TTT) is not a listed treatment for retinal detachment.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset floaters and perception of a curtain in front of his right eye, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most probable diagnosis for a patient presenting with sudden onset floaters and the perception of a curtain in front of the eye is Retinal Detachment (RD). Floaters in RD are often due to associated vitreous hemorrhage. A visual field defect described as a black curtain or veil in front of the eye is a characteristic symptom of retinal detachment.

  • Rhegmatogenous RD (RRD) involves a rhegma (retinal break) through which liquefied vitreous gains access to and accumulates beneath the neurosensory retina, leading to detachment.
  • Common predisposing factors for RRD include high myopia (due to peripheral retinal degenerations like lattice degeneration, holes, and breaks, along with vitreous liquefaction), trauma, aphakia, and pseudophakia.
  • Other premonitory symptoms of RD include photopsia (flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break).
  • Loss of vision occurs when the detachment involves the macula.
  • Signs of RD include a decrease in visual acuity, hypotony (due to absorption of subretinal fluid through the RPE), Shafer's sign (pigments in the anterior vitreous, also known as "tobacco dusting," indicating a fresh RD).
  • A detached retina appears convex in configuration, with a corrugated surface and free undulation, and a break is typically identified at the periphery.

Explanation of Other Options:

VH- Vitreous Hemorrhage (Option A): While sudden onset floaters are a common symptom of vitreous hemorrhage, the distinct perception of a "curtain" or "veil" obscuring a portion of the visual field strongly points to a retinal detachment, which involves the physical displacement of retinal tissue.

Eales disease (Option C): Eales disease is an idiopathic inflammatory condition primarily affecting peripheral retinal veins, leading to recurrent vitreous hemorrhages and neovascularization. While it can cause floaters due to hemorrhage, the "curtain" symptom is not its primary defining visual field characteristic.

Glaucoma (Option D): Glaucoma is a group of diseases characterized by progressive optic nerve damage, often associated with elevated intraocular pressure. It typically causes gradual, progressive loss of peripheral vision (leading to "tunnel vision") rather than the sudden onset of floaters and a curtain-like visual field defect.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sudden onset floaters and the perception of a "curtain" or "veil" in the visual field are hallmark symptoms highly suggestive of Retinal Detachment (RD).
  • Other symptoms of RD include photopsia, and signs can include decreased visual acuity, hypotony, and Shafer's sign.
  • The primary treatment for RD is surgery, including scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy, or pars plana vitrectomy.

questions.text: A young patient with a history of using glasses for the past 10 years comes with complaints of photopsia and sudden loss of vision in the right eye. Which of the following tests should be done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of photopsia (flashes) and sudden loss of vision, combined with a history of using glasses for 10 years (suggesting myopia), strongly hint at a possible peripheral retinal break which could progress to Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RD). Therefore, this patient should undergo a thorough peripheral retinal screening. The most appropriate test for this is Indirect Ophthalmoscopy with scleral indentation. If a retinal break is identified, prophylactic laser barrage should be performed to prevent RD.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cycloplegic Refraction (Option A): Cycloplegic refraction determines the refractive error of the eye by paralyzing the ciliary muscle. While useful for accurate prescription, it is not the primary test for diagnosing acute retinal pathology like a retinal break or detachment.

Gonioscopy (Option B): Gonioscopy is a technique used to examine the iridocorneal angle, which is relevant for glaucoma diagnosis and management. It is not indicated for assessing peripheral retinal breaks or detachment.

Direct ophthalmoscopy (Option C): Direct ophthalmoscopy provides an upright, magnified view of a small area of the posterior pole of the retina. It has a limited field of view and is less effective for peripheral retinal examination and detecting breaks, especially compared to indirect ophthalmoscopy with scleral indentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Photopsia and sudden vision loss in a myopic patient suggest a peripheral retinal break or early retinal detachment.
  • Indirect ophthalmoscopy with scleral indentation is the gold standard for comprehensive peripheral retinal examination and identifying retinal breaks.
  • Early detection and treatment (e.g., laser barrage) of such breaks can prevent the progression to retinal detachment.

questions.text: Retinal Detachment (RD) most commonly associated with Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The type of Retinal Detachment (RD) most commonly associated with Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) is Tractional Retinal Detachment (TRD). TRD occurs when fibrovascular membranes in the vitreous, often a result of long-standing vitreous hemorrhage, exert traction on the retina, pulling it forward and causing detachment.

  • Other causes of Tractional RD include: Central retinal vein occlusion, Eales' disease, and Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP).
  • Signs of TRD include a detached retina with a concave configuration, with the highest elevation at the site of the tractional band. There are typically no breaks seen, and the retina shows minimal mobility.
  • The primary treatment for TRD is Pars plana vitrectomy and endophotocoagulation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rhegmatogenous RD (Option A): Rhegmatogenous RD is caused by a retinal break (rhegma) allowing liquefied vitreous to pass beneath the neurosensory retina. While PDR can sometimes lead to rhegmatogenous components (e.g., if traction causes a break), its primary and most common association is with tractional forces, not primarily a rhegma.

Exudative RD (Option C): Exudative RD occurs due to fluid accumulation from the choroid in the subretinal space, often from inflammatory conditions, tumors, or systemic diseases like toxemia of pregnancy. It is not typically caused by the direct tractional forces associated with PDR.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tractional Retinal Detachment (TRD) is the type of retinal detachment most commonly associated with Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR).
  • TRD results from fibrovascular membranes exerting traction on the retina.
  • TRD is characterized by a concave retinal configuration and no retinal breaks.
  • Treatment for TRD often involves pars plana vitrectomy.

questions.text: Split at the level of Outer plexiform Layer occurs in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Retinoschisis is a condition characterized by the splitting of the neurosensory retina, often accompanied by vitreous degeneration. It is classified into two main types: Typical retinoschisis and Reticular retinoschisis. The split at the level of the Outer Plexiform Layer specifically occurs in Typical retinoschisis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atypical Retinoschisis (Option B): Atypical retinoschisis refers to unusual presentations of retinoschisis.

Reticular Retinoschisis (Option C): Reticular retinoschisis is a type of retinoschisis where the splitting occurs at the level of the Nerve Fibre Layer. It is seen more commonly in hypermetropes in the inferotemporal periphery of the retina.

None (Option D): As Typical Retinoschisis is defined by a split at the Outer Plexiform Layer, this option is incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

  • Retinoschisis involves the splitting of the neurosensory retina.
  • Typical retinoschisis is characterized by a split at the level of the Outer Plexiform Layer.
  • Reticular retinoschisis is characterized by a split at the level of the Nerve Fibre Layer.
